behaviours.description: Many people arrive in hospital under a Section 136 of the Mental Health Act. A Section 136 is a police power to detain an individual upto 24 hours in a place of safety.  A place of safety usually is a psychiatric hospital. Further information can be found here: https://www.rethink.org/advice-and-information/rights-restrictions/mental-health-laws/section-136-of-the-mental-health-act

Doctors can make an assessment under Section 2 and/or Section 3 of the Mental Health Act.  A Section 2 permits detention of upto 28 days in hospital and a Section 3 permits detention upto 6 months in hospital. A Section 3 can follow a Section 2 or some may just be given a Section 3 straight away. Section 2 and 3 are often known as being "Sectioned". Section 3's can be continously renewed. Further information can be found here: https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/legal-rights/sectioning/about-sectioning
A Doctor or other approved clinician in charge can detain a Informal patient (someone not sectioned) for upto 72 hours under Section 5(2) of the Mental Health Act.
A Nurse can detain a Voluntary patient (someone not sectioned) for upto 6 hours under Section 5(4) of the Mental Health Act.
People sectioned are not permitted to leave the ward without their section ending or having legal leave to do so.
People should be served legal papers of their section if they ask for it but this may not happen or with delay.

People are required to take the medications they are prescribed. Refusal to take medication may lead to being forced medication without your consent if your sectioned as well as other penalities (such as no leave or being sectioned if you are a informal patient).

Doctors can give leave to people under Section 17 of the Mental Health Act.  This is usually escorted leave where a staff member escorts you on leave (such as to a local shop). Usually there isn't the staff available to do escorted leave so escorted leave is meaningless to many people. Unescorted leave can often be given by the Doctor after a period of a person being marked for (though not necessarily receiving) escorted leave.

All sectioned people are entitled to a government funded Independent Mental Health Advocate (IMHA). Advocates can be helpful in challenging Doctors opinions and helping sectioned people get their view across. Further Information can be found here: https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/guides-to-support-and-services/advocacy/imhas-england

adjustments.description: The anxiety and sensory challenges for an Autistic person should be reviewed. Questions should be asked if the sensory challenges are magnified in the present situation.  For example is the physical environment causing meltdowns or shutdowns.  Helping to soothe an individual by moving them to a quiet room to ease the situation before assessment.

Communicating with the Autistic person non-threateningly and in a non-confrontational approach may elicit a better response. If Autistic people are asked what is happening and asked what their wishes are then the situation may be resolved more appropriately. Don't judge Autistic people by their voice tone and eye contact as way to assess their mental state. Communicating clearly and directly can be of assistance.  Don't speak in medical jargon like as if they are a disease. Speak to a Autistic person using language that is accessible and can be easily understood. Give the Autistic person time and space to process information. Check if the Autistic person understands what you are communicating. Give the Autistic person breathing space.  This means not surrounding the Autistic person with crowds of people watching within a short space. The use of the written word such as writing or mobile text messages may be a simple non-verbal way to communicate. Communication that requires simple responses like nodding of the head may be adequate to begin with. Include the Autistic person in decision making and be willing to explain everything that is going on.

Autistic people want to be treated as human beings.  Talking to them at their own level rather than standing over them. Providing reasurance rather than confrontation. Giving people food and drink is often a way of connecting with people.  Doing the same for an Autistic person in crisis may make the difference. Talking to an Autistic person about their special interests can also form connection.

First responders to situations (such as the police and paramedics) need to be suitably trained in Autism.  Real practical application of this training is of high importance and not just an item on a to-do list.

A meltdown is when a Autistic person becomes completely overwhelmed by their current situation and temporarily loses control of their behaviour. A shutdown is when a Autistic person is not themselves and are only able to focus on basic needs. Restraining an Autistic person in a meltdown or shutdown can be traumatic. Much can be done to prevent meltdowns and shutdowns before they happen by knowing the causes, triggers, sensory considerations, anxieties and changes in routine. Giving the Autistic person space to calm down and providing anything that soothes them can make a difference.

events.event_name: Detention and Rights under the Mental Health Act

behaviours.description: A Informal Patient is a person not sectioned but chooses to stay on the ward for treatment may not consent to medication and leave the ward. However, refusal to take medication or obeying norms of the psychiatric hospital may lead to being "sectioned".

An Informal patient usually has time limited unsecorted leave but this can be limited.  Limitations can include a lack of staff to do a risk assessment to unlock the door to an outbreak like COVID that puts the ward into lockdown).
A informal Patient has no right to a government funded Independent Mental Health Advocate (IMHA).  Though not a legal entitlement some charities offer Community Advocacy.

events.event_name: Detention and Rights as Informal Patient

behaviours.description: People are expected to source their clothes from friends or relatives.  If this is not possible, the hospital staff will provide (if you ask only) NHS issue pyjamas or nightwear. There are no social workers or support workers to source clothes from your home.

People are expected to source their toiletries and any other needed belongings from friends or relatives. If you cannot source these then you are forced to go without.  Many people resort to ordering items online from their phones.
People may be able to receive small packs of shower gel and shampoo from staff (these may or may not be available).

People wishing to have a shave will often be encouraged to use an electric shaver but you will need to provide your own. Although traditional razors are permitted staff tend to not like to supervise their use so may make up excuses perhaps due to a claimed staff shortage. Use of a traditional razor or electric shaver will still require observation in most cases.

People may be allowed to order takeaways.  Different wards have different rules. A common challenge is the takeaway is delivered but not to you. Someone at the door or beyond intercepts it and it doesn't arrive.

People are usually allowed to order items into the hospital.  This could be things like shower gel, groceries or a jigsaw puzzle. A common challenge is the item is delivered but gets stuck for a few days at door security or beyond. None of the staff claim to know anything about the delivered package then it just appears days after it is delivered.

Psychiatrists are ideologically conditioned to believe medication is the answer for people detained in hospital. The "Gold Standard" for treatment is medication like Lithium to a Psychiatrist while it’s a monetary system abandoned in the 20th Century to many who study Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE). There are many points of view to human suffering.

Meal times (usually breakfast, lunch, dinner and supper) are at set times during the day and you are expected to queue (some people may push in without penalty).  If you miss a meal you will usually be expected to go without. Meals may have 2 or more options.  Meals can be served on plastic crockery and cutlery.
People are expected to ask for towels.
People staying may get their own room or sleep in a dorm with other people.  People may not be allowed in their own room all day. Each room may have its own en suite shower.
The lounge usually has a television protected by a wooden cabinet. People may need to source the remote control from staff or knock on the staff office. The remote can often go missing.
People are expected to take their queries to staff.  This may mean visiting the staff office.  However, knocking on the staff office can lead to no answer and being ignored.
People usually have the option of Tea and Coffee.  Sometimes water and squash. These provisions may not be always be available as the staff don't always maintain them continously.
People may be expected to leave areas being cleaned such as your room or the lounge.
People can expect their rooms to be inspected by staff regularly.
People are not allowed certain items like mobile phone charging cables and flowers.  The staff may have a safe place to charge your phone but you will be expected to provide your own charging cable.
People refer to "Ward round" as the weekly appointment with the psychiatrists and other junior staff.
Breaking the rules of the ward that upset most patients and staff.
Changing the TV channel that most people are watching.
Drinking the milk directly from the bottle so no one can make tea or coffee hygienically.
Most law breaking will be deemed minor as people on the ward are considered to lack any capacity.

adjustments.description: A quiet ward for people that are Autistic and near discharge would be less overwhelming. Providing sensory items like stress balls, bean bags, squidgy, fidget cubes, Rubik’s cubes and chew toys or foods. Providing sensory mitigation aids like ear defenders, ear plugs, sleep masks for the eyes and sunglasses. Supporting a soothing environment with weighted blankets, lavender bags, quiet rooms with massage chairs or beds.

Communicating with the Autistic person non-threateningly and in a non-confrontational approach may elicit a better response. If Autistic people are asked if they are ok and asked what their wishes are then their needs are more likely to be met. Don't judge Autistic people by their voice tone and eye contact as way to assess their mental state. Communicating clearly and directly can be of assistance.  Don't speak in medical jargon like as if they are a disease. Speak to a Autistic person using language that is accessible and can be easily understood. Give the Autistic person time and space to process information. Check if the Autistic person understands what you are communicating. Give the Autistic person breathing space.  This means not surrounding the Autistic person with crowds of people watching within a short space. Include the Autistic person in decision making and be willing to explain everything that is going on.

Autistic people want to be treated as human beings.  Talking to them at their own level rather than standing over them. Providing reasurance rather than confrontation. Talking to an Autistic person about their special interests can also form connection.

Understand it is extra challenging for an Autistic person in hospital.  They have nowhere to escape from sensory overload which may mean they burn out to a meltdown or shutdown. An Autistic person may not have the items they need with them in hospital in order to stim and/or relax.  Items like stress balls, mobile phones and books may be part of a Autistic persons routine that they no longer have full access too. Autistic people often suffer from anxiety and are not able to advocate for their needs which may mean they go to a meltdown without any warning signs its going to occur.

A meltdown is when a Autistic person becomes completely overwhelmed by their current situation and temporarily loses control of their behaviour. A shutdown is when a Autistic person is not themselves and are only able to focus on basic needs. Restraining an Autistic person in a meltdown or shutdown can be traumatic. Much can be done to prevent meltdowns and shutdowns before they happen by knowing the causes, triggers, sensory considerations, anxieties and changes in routine. Giving the Autistic person space to calm down and providing anything that soothes them can make a difference. The culture of a psychiatric ward can involve "patients kicking off" (disruptive behaviour) and often leading to restraint.  An Autistic meltdown may appear like the Autistic person is "kicking off" when in actual fact it is due to a need not being met. It's common for an Autistic person to go into shutdown after the meltdown. Repeatedly asking the Autistic person questions (usually a member of staff examining the person) after the meltdown while in shutdown is not usually helpful.  Asking the Autistic person a few hours or days after the event when they are relaxed why the meltdown happened will be more helpful.

behaviours.description: During Ward Round the Doctor may give people options on their medication.  This may or may not be a genuine choice. The Doctor should provide more information if asked but this may not happen.
People who are sectioned can be given medication without consent.  This may include using restraint in order to make the person comply.

People are restrained by ward staff if they feel its necessary. There are different points of view on what is necessary but this can include safety, violence and poor training in how to de-escalate a situation or prevent it developing in the first place.
Refusing medication may lead to restraint in order to make the person comply.
